reviewText: You're thrown into an open world. You're given targets that you must kill, and in some instances, objectives to complete. That's it, the rest is up to you. You decide your weapon of choice to pull off the perfect hit; will it be the pistol? Shotgun? Assault Rifle? Submachine Gun? Sniper Rifle? You can spend the money that you earn from hits on different upgrades. Will you opt for a silencer on your pistol, or will you spend it on improved lockpicking skills? There are multiple different playstyles, and the choice is entirely up to you. Will you run in, guns blazing, killing anything that stands between you and your target? Or will you sneak in, using a disguise you stole from a guard that is now unconcious in the dumpster? How will you kill your targets? Will you poison their food? Strangle them? Snipe them? Rig a chandelier to fall on them? You choose how you play the game. You choose your definition of a perfect hit. First time players beware, however, you will find yourself spending lots of time doing trial-and-error to find the best ways to kill your target. If you enjoy games with linear gameplay where there's only one way to win, then you will probably not enjoy this game. However, if you want a sandbox stealth experience, where you get to decide how the game will play out, at $8.99, this game is perfect for you.

reviewText:
When people talk Hitman there's usually one game they have in mind and that's Blood Money. Hitman is a series that boasted a novel concept which has somehow managed to remain pretty unique to this day (seriously - how many disguise-based stealth games are there?) and that gameplay evolved from game to game with Blood Money being the pinnacle (since Absolution went in a somewhat different direction closer to other stealth franchises like Splinter Cell).

Above all Blood Money is an action adventure game. Each mission provides quite a huge and open area with one ore more targets which need to be assassinated as well as the occasional non-assassination goal. Each map features many characters following basic routines and items or statics objects which can somehow be put to use. The beauty of Hitman lies in exploring the big and diverse environments, discovering usable objects, observing the targets and bystanders and then putting a brilliant plan together - and somewhat ironically the best and toughest plan is always the one where nobody dies, except for the targets of course. It gets even more complicated when you wish to make the deaths look like accidents and leave nothing behind (especially not that precious suit!). But even once you've developed that brilliant plan, there's still the matter of execution which requires perfect timing, with wits, patience and a good memory being the key to success - one mistake and everything goes to hell and there's not much left to do except mowing down everyone in your path.

As an action game Hitman is definitely sub-par but if you're up for it and are willing to spend ages on the same mission until you find and execute that perfect plan (or at least one perfect plan as often there's several ways to get that awesome Silent Assassin rating) there's nothing quite like it and a truly rewarding experience awaits you.

There's not much going on in terms of story, which is told through non-interactive cutscenes, but that doesn't keep the game from providing many very original locations and missions depicting the criminal underworld from a wide variety of angles, mostly ones you don't know from other games. To top it all off the action is accompanied by one of the greatest soundtracks to be ever heard in a video game, composed by legendary Jesper Kyd, providing a truly surreal atmosphere at times. What kind of graphics to expect everyone can clearly see on the screenshots.

Bottom line: if you are looking for an original stealth game or just want to know what all this Hitman talk is about - this is the game to go with.

reviewText:
Hitman Blood Money is an epitome of the Sandbox genre. This game requires skill and patience with almost endless possibilities to every mission. Not only are you allowed almost infinite options on how you come to face your target, but also how you chose to eliminate them.

Blood Money also offers an enjoyable experience to Stealth fans, but with a different approach. A majority of stealth games pride themselves on wall-to-wall, shadow-to-shadow gameplay; and while this can be very enjoyable and exciting; there are different ways to enjoy a stealth style experience; Blood Money is one of them! You are keeping your true identity hidden, not letting the enemy guards notice that their perimeter is breached; not allowing anyone to know you are even there. And when it all goes belly-up it still offers just as an enjoyable time trying to dig your-self out of that mess!

Obviously Blood Money has a few dated features like glitchy ragdolls; dated textures and filtering. But when you look past this, you see a game that far surpasses most modern day games in areas specifically such as the plot and level design. But if you are a gamer who when searching for new games mainly looks at the visual side of things, this may not be for you.

Blood Money also offers the ability for players to customize certain weapons with features such as silencers, scopes; different ammo types etc. Sadly, not all weapons found throughout the game allow you to do so, but this feature is still only found in very few games; including those of the current high budget new-releases.

If I were playing this game at the time it was first released, it would have been a game with no noticeable flaws, but certain dated features cannot be ignored by today’s standards. Although the game’s base design is still without a doubt, impeccable, as are its plots and levels.

Hitman: Blood Money is pretty cool, I guess.


You play as Agent 47, a genetically engineered super assassin created solely to take out the trash. And by trash, I mean murder. The game takes place through various points in Agent 47's life, going from location to location and drowning as many people in their toilets as physically possible. While all this is going on, a reporter is getting a story on Agent 47 from a mysterious man describes his toilet-drowning life.

The game is a stealth game but not like you'd suspect. You don't hide in the shadows or repeat the last persons sentence in the form of a question. Instead you're out in the open, blending into society the best way a man can with a barcode on the back of his big beautiful bald head. Get use to it, because you're gonna be staring at it for awhile, not just because you can play the game in third person, but because it's beautiful. I mean, look at it, it's so shiny.

Each mission you are given the task of murdering someone who probably has it coming, you do this by planning out an attack, playing dress up like I used to with Polly Pocket because my mom refused to buy me any G.I. Joes because they would encourage  meto be a strong male role model for children. Thanks mom.

Now, with the right equipment and the perfect shade of underwear, you go on the attack, soloing out people at their most vulernable and promptly drowning them in a toilet. Way to go!

You'd think that this whole murder shtick would get boring after awhile considering it's all you do, but surprise! It doesn't. THe new locations, difficulty of your target, and unique ways you end up drowning others in toilets keeps the game fresh. It's by no means an easy game, unless you're me. Then it's super easy because you're super good and I have a history of drowning others in toilets.

Keep that last bit to yourself.

But when drowning others in toilets isn't an option or you're just a complete chump, the game gives you a plethora of weapons to go on a murderous rampage with. These include Agent 47's iconic handguns, the silver ballers. They are baller. See what I did there?  While the shooting is nothing special, the guns have just enough OOMF to be entertaining to fire, especially when you send people out doing back flips with hand gun bullets.

But surely there's a punishment for going crazy, right? There is, and it digs deep. Not only will the game detract money you can use on new weapons and upgrades, it will also call you a total loser. After each hit, you get a newspaper describing the incident where you're called anything from a Silent Assassins, to a ghost, to a skulking man who drowns people in toilets. The more damage you do and the less inconspicuous you are, the less money you have to spend on yourself. So no new Xbox for poor Agent 47, you horrible person.

But should you play Hitman: Blood Money?

I will admit, this is probably the last Hitman game you'll play that feels like an honest Hitman game. While it does seem odd for an angry looking man in a bird suit to not look suspicious, the disguise mechanics is what gave the game that flavor it needed to stand out from its competitors like Thief or Splinter Cell. It's fun, it makes you feel like a badass when you succesfully pull off the perfect hit, and it's easy to look over it's problems just by how fun the game is on it's own.

reviewText:
The best Hitman game ever made and by far one of the best Stealth Assassin games ever made.

Pros & Features:
This is a game that lets play with a number of playstyles. If you play like a pro you'll play Silent Assassin difficulty and never be satisfied until you have a Silent Assassin ranking on all missions, which rewards you with the most cash and the highest rating.

You can blend in with crowds, disguise yourself as NPC's and watch NPC behavior, using a wide variety of methods to assassinate your targets. You can even make deaths look like accidents on most levels.

Alternately you can murder anyone you want, or everyone if you really want a massacre in the newspaper.

Yes, at the end of each mission you get a newspaper report that mentions the number of people found dead, the number of witnesses, whether or not there were signs of a professional assassination, and whether or not deaths are believed to be natural or accidents rather than assasinations.

In addition to being a professional assassin you can collect weapons from missions, adding an element of replayability, additionally you can upgrade your own weapons and gear with cash you collect from missions.

The game has gamepad support and works great with mouse and keyboard, it's well worth purchasing.

It's a damn shame that there has never been another game like Hitman Blood Money.

Cons & Drawbacks:
The controls are rather clunky at times, in a way that adds to the stealth focus but it also just feels and looks clunky sometimes.

The graphics are a bit dated. Still passible but dated.

The voice acting is sometimes hilariously bad, that may be intentional though as there is a lot of dark humor.

reviewText:
Hitman: Blood Money is generally regarded as the best game in the series and definitely lives up to its reputation. Previous games had been plagued by bugs, poor design decisions, and overall unfair situations. This time around, the developers seem to have taken note of what went wrong with previous installations of the series and as a result they have produced a highly polished and well executed hitman game.

As per the Hitman formula, most missions require a few trial runs to learn all the necessary elements such as guard positions, entry points, and target vulnerabilities required to perform the necessary executions with maximum efficiency and stealth. In order to get the best rating, it is almost mandatory to study each level in depth to see where your targets will be at their weakest.

One thing I noticed with this installment of the series is the introduction of well-handled crowd elements. This feature really shines in the “Murder of Crows” mission where you have to wade through crowds of revelers during Mardi Gras in order to track and eliminate several targets. Other new entries to the series include notoriety which can increase upon being spotted (yellow) or from CCTV sightings, which can be rectified through securing security tapes. There is also the addition of a new execution technique (strangulation) that can be done via elevator hatch above a target.

The only downside to this game, and this seems to be a trend for what it’s worth, is the final mission. All of a sudden, despite having done a majority of the game almost entirely in stealth, you are required to gun down an entire area full of trigger happy NPCs. I found it to be entirely inappropriate to the overall storyline not to mention my preferred style of play (silent assassin). Nevertheless, I managed to find a way to take a human shield and plow through the finale. If it were not for that final mission, I would consider Blood Money to be a perfect game. Regardless, it still lives up to its reputation and will likely live on to be the best that Hitman has to offer.

Good Luck, 47

Hitman is a fantastic sandbox puzzle game. Yeah, the nature of having fun playing as an assassin is morally questionable, but if it makes you feel any better most of 47's targets are terrible people. The story that ties your missions together is really interesting, too.

In the level Curtains Down you must take out a politician and an opera singer, both tied to an underage prostitution ring, in an opera house during the recital. There's a prop gun used during one of the acts, and another agent has hidden a real version of that gun in a coat that, if you choose, you can claim at the front door. Here are just a few of the many ways you can go about this task:

The singer:

-Replace the prop gun with the real gun during one of the scheduled breaks between rehearsals. The gun is used in an execution sequence in the opera, so it's an instant fatality.

-Take a pistol along with you and skip the prop gun. Make your way to the back of the stage OR to the lighting rigging on top and fire the pistol at the exact moment the prop gun is fired in the execution scene.

-Don't bother with the execution sequence entirely and run to the opera singer's dressing room, turn off his light, and hide in his closet until he comes in to go over some of his lines in private. If you want to take him out with a melee attack you have to shoot the dressing room mirror before he arrives, or else he will see you coming when you sneak up on him.

-Bring some explosives along with you and sneak your way up to the top of the opera house and plant a bomb on the lighting rigging above the actor. When the actor gets up on stage trigger your bomb and make sure you're far away from anyone that might notice you when you do.

-Just be an idiot and shoot everything in the opera house if you want to roleplay as a crazy person.

The politician:

-If the opera singer does not get up after the execution sequence the politician will run over to the bottom of aisles to gasp. He'll stand there for just enough time for a bomb planted on the chandelier above him to cause the chandelier to mysteriously fall on him.

-You can replace the prop gun with a real gun and then bring another pistol along with you. Set yourself up in the lighting rafters and, during the execution sequence, shoot the politician at the exact moment the real version of the prop gun is fired.

-You can take out the politician with a silenced sniper rifle at any time

-You can take out one of his guards and then disguise yourself as one. Once the opera singer goes down and he begins his run towards the aisles you can take him out in one of the staircases without any people on them.

I just described how you can take out your targets, I didn't describe any of the many paths you can take to get to those points, or the disguises that you might use. This is just ONE level in the game, and there are many more like it.

reviewText:
Murder 101
‘Hitman: Blood Money’ is the fourth entry in the iconic Stealth / Strategy RPG Hitman series, and is simply put, the best game of the franchise. Gorgeous visuals, well designed levels, intuitive gameplay and a compelling storyline make this title Agent 47’s defining moment.

Campaign: Released by Eidos / IO Interactive in 2007, ‘Blood Money’ puts gamers back in the familiar shoes of Agent 47 – a professional assassin who is both ruthlessly efficient and disarmingly charming at the same time. The campaign details 47’s first foray across the Atlantic, and its 13 missions take you around the world to varying locales and vastly differing settings - from mountain retreats in the Rockies to Opera Houses in Paris, from Casino’s in Las Vegas to Jungle Hideaway’s in Chile. The missions are seamlessly woven into a broader narrative of the FBI’s efforts to connect the dots in a series of high profile assassinations and the surprising twist ending ensures your attention is kept throughout.

Graphics | Sound | Gameplay: Graphically, the game is beautiful, with detailed, lush environments, atmospheric sound and some of the best level design seen in modern gaming. Each mission has several objectives that need to be completed – but be aware – there is no handholding here. True to its ‘Hitman’ roots, ‘Blood Money’ drops you into a large open world level with the freedom to accomplish your objectives in any order you see fit, and you are largely left to figure out the best way to get at your targets and escape unnoticed. Every mission, even every target, can be approached in multiple ways limited seemingly only by your imagination – Sniper kills from afar, close up strangulation with Piano Wire, a poisoned beverage to a distracted gory death are but some of the options at your disposal.  Tight and intuitive K&M controls, a broad selection of weapons, tools and distraction items, and upgradable items available for purchase in-between missions round out your toolkit.

Flaws: The game also addresses many of the core gameplay issues and complaints of previous installments while at the same time moving the series forward – the inclusion of plentiful in-game save options, much improved AI, ability to play in both 3rd person and first-person views and high replayability make finding fault difficult. If pressed, a few gripes would be some clunky character animations and a close adherence to the Hitman formula making things seem quite familiar to veterans of the series.

Overall, ‘Hitman: Blood Money’ is 47’s finest hour – a visually stunning, atmospheric, Stealth / Strategy RPG that puts you in the shoes of the iconic assassin and where you are ultimately limited only by your imagination in finding new ways to eliminate your target. Highly Recommended – Rated (9/10)

reviewText:
This is a great game and definitely the best game in the Hitman series, and probably one of the best stealth games overall. In Blood Money you play as a very scary looking and highly dangerous man in large open ended environments hunting down assassination targets and killing them, preferably as quietly and skillfully as possible. And that's pretty much the game in a nutshell, there's no real story and the gameplay isn't too complex.

However what Hitman does do, It does extremely well. The levels are HUGE and there are multiple routes to take and a very wide range of ways to murder your targets, and because of the open endedness it can lead to a lot of cool ''yeah I meant to do that'' type moments, a plan can completely fall apart or things may play out differently than you intended, but you can take one of the other god knows how many routes there may be and still take down your target and get away without leaving a trace, so as you can tell the gameplay is very organic and nonlinear compared to something like Absolution, which makes it extremely replayable because you're going to want to try new things and see how else you can pull off an awesome assassination.

I also love how despite how grim the game itself is with all the murder and ominous music and stuff, you can kill people while dressed as santa claus, or a f*cking giant bird, sniping another darker bird through a window (NOT RACIST) It strikes a nice balance between being grim and comedic, so the game never get's dull for me.

The gunplay could've been a bit more refined though, many times If things happen to go badly for you, chances are you won't survive a gunfight because of how flimsy and at times, unresponsive the aiming is, (However first person mode does help a little bit) and there's no kind of quick dodge type manouever, all you can do is awkwardly strafe and hope that the enemy has very sh*t aim, on the normal difficulty you can take a fair amount of bullets, but the enemies call their mates pretty quickly and you're gonna end up filled with holes faster than you can say ''f*ck''. Though some people might say this is a good thing because It incentivises you to be more sneaky, I'd say that it prevents an organic and fluid means of escaping the situation, It's actually pretty jarring since you suddenly become as stiff as Robocop. But for the most part I'm good at planning out my kills so things don't go awry very often, so the shooting doesn't bother me very much.

Personally, I can look past the lack of a story and complexity simply because of how fun and organic the gameplay is, there are many routes to take, many ways to plan out your murder and a crapton of ways to actually pull them off.

Great game, get it all full price.

reviewText:
If you're looking for an assassination sim, then this is THE game to play.

For starters, the game gives you practically limitless freedom in every mission (except in the final mission of course, but no one likes that mission) and the game has tons of variety from mission to mission, in terms of both settings and the enviromental kills you can use.

The sheer size of the levels will complete overwhelm you intially; making success seem almost impossible. But through countless restarts, you'll slowly piece together a plan to kill your targets in the most effective way possible, making the game feel like a puzzle game at times.

What's more, the levels are highly replayable thanks to a scoring system that encourages you to be as discreet as possible; meaning you'll have a few late nights trying to get the highest rank on a particular mission- and it's extremely fun to do.

Other than having a linear tutorial and the aforementioned awful final mission, this game has very few flaws. It also runs well on mediocre gaming PCs, which is also a plus.

Overall, if games like Assassin's Creed are a little to loud" for your liking

reviewText:
Truly the model when it comes to assassin stealth games.  Hitman Blood Money is a game about finding and eliminating targets in a multitude of scenarios ranging from a party in a vineyard, to suburbia, to a casino, and a mardi-gras street fest.  This game is non-linear and each level presents many options for eliminating your target.  Do you go quiet and kill your target by switching the prop gun with a real replica?  Do you equip your machine gun and go in guns blazing?  Do you slit his throat in the dressing room?  The level of options for each level make this the best hitman game to date.

Small detractments from this game include some wacky AI choices and some difficult movement elements (going through windows can sometimes be a pain and AI can sometimes spaz out and find you etc.)  But don't be discouraged, the positives in this game far outweigh the negatives.

I recently rebought this game on steam because I lost my CD.  I'm enjoying this playthrough just like I enjoyed the dozens of hours I experienced through my retail copy.

Take it from a TF2 spy main.  This game presents assassination in a creative and entertaining manner that will have you coming back for more and more.

reviewText: This is the first Hitman game i've ever played, and i liked it more than i thought i would. It's essentially a puzzle game set inside real-world sandboxes - you walk around in plain sight trying to figure out how to best distract or impersonate the guards to get to your target and then get back out again. It is very refreshing to play a game that has a true-to-life amount of civilians walking around in it instead of being stuck in abandoned city blocks or enemy bases. Of course, if you start attacking those civilians indiscriminately, you will be dead in no seconds flat. Really cool concept.\n\nThe unfortunate thing is that the game is designed around trial and error. You have to die over and over to figure out what places you are allowed to go, and to figure out the movements of your targets. You also get limited saves, so eventually it just gets frustrating. It's a testament to the game that even after i started using walkthroughs to figure out where to go without having to repeat sections over and over it was pretty fun. If you are into pure stealth spy games (there are no dialog options/conversation challenges), it's certainly worth the pittance it goes for these days.

reviewText:
Blood Money is the 4th game in the Hitman franchise - released in 2006, 6 years before the next episode reached completion in development. It took IO Interactive quite a long time to develop the latest episode for the game industry's (probably) most famous assassin. As to what caused this postponement I do not know - perhaps the reception of Blood Money had been negative or somewhat mixed. My feelings about the game are only positive and I salute IO for making such an amazing, stealth-based action-adventure software that offers high replayability due to the various difficulty settings available.

Blood Money gives us a different setting in each mission. Hitman eliminates a gang on a riverboat in Mississippi, approaches a drug lord in Chile, takes down members of a rivaling organisation during a street festival, eliminates a sheikh in a casino in Vegas and more! Every level is very different from its predecessor - it requires different tactics and it is very important to pay attention to your surroundings, i.e. where the enemies are, what their patrolling route is, what disguises you need for them not to be able to recognise you etc. Attention to detail is top notch. The game looks good, runs well and has very decent voice acting. Music was composed by Jesper Kyd who later on presented us with the excellent score of Assassins Creed.

More than one solution exists to solve a mission. The game, therefore, is varied and offers replayability as some solutions require more finesse and while they offer you the easy way out (i.e. no violent encounters) the execution can hold you for hours. In fact, a higher difficulty setting allows you only to save fewer times so you really need to plan every move carefully. Higher difficulty levels yield you with extra money after the mission as the game offers no achievements. More money means better weapons and gadgets at your disposal. But if you prefer the stealth approach you will not purchase new weapons or upgrade your existing ones with the extra sum - you, instead, will use this to bribe key people to decrease your notoriety. Also, when you play the game for the first time, it is advisable to purchase information; information that helps you with the solution in each mission in the form of tips, personal messages.

In Hitman you need to obtain a disguise all the time to get past certain points in the level. While stealth-based games are many I do not recall any of these out there offering this option. In many cases you need to use more than one disguise and just to make the game more challenging you get extra money for reaching the extraction point in your tuxedo, how you originally started your mission. Even the story is interesting and has some surprises - just to mention the name of some locations towards the end of it would be a spoiler so you can find it out for yourselves.

Blood Money is an exceptionally good game. Absolution is the next-gen" version of Hitman - but if you don't mind playing a challenging and exciting game that is 6 years old Blood Money is for you.

The customizable weapons are nice, but all you really need to beat missions are your trusty syringes garrote wire.

reviewText:
Hitman: Blood Money...so rage inducing yet you can't stop trying. You need a huge amount of patience for this game. I have patience, but sometimes it can take a very long time to figure out exactly how to do things without getting yourself killed. There are elements in this game that are unmatched even to this day. This is the only franchise where you can change outfits and actually go in disguise freely.

You need to watch movements and it's a whole lot of trial and error in every single contract you have. But when you figure it out, it feels so rewarding knowing you had the determination and critical thinking to pull it off. And you can always go back and see if it can be done differently. I only completed the first real level; but I've played enough to judge the game. I think despite some irritating problems, it's a good game and it aged well.

And just a side note: If you haven't played Absolution and you're wondering whether or not to get it...yes it's worth the money. All the diehard Hitman fans are just butthurt because the new developers decided to change some things around to try something new. That doesn't make it a bad game. I do however agree that the new stealth system is rather dumb at times since you use energy to hide your face even when you're in disguise. It has more of a Splinter Cell feel for sure; but it still has the Hitman elements we all expect.

reviewText:
This game is by far the best Hitman in the series, even till this day. The playability, even on this platform, is exceptional. No lagging, rendering and most of all no crashing (windows 8). Despite having a lot of options and weapons and ways to use them etc... everything is easy to use after the tutorial mission, nothing too complex. The graphics are awesome, especially taking into account that this game was released over 8 years ago!

Hours of fun is to be had with this game, it's entertaining to go and play the game back to do things a little different and see which route to take is the most rewarding one. The introduction of new systems in the series such as a cash system, notoriety system and conventionally a rating system. Each one tying everything in the game together, demontrating why your approach has earned you your reputation/money whether good or bad. Axiomatically the stealth route is the most fruitful, but to blast your way through the game and become notorious can be extremely fun too.

There are 13 immersive and addicting levels in the game, each taking around 30-60 minutes to complete, so you will certainly have hours of fun. Each level is beautifully designed and shrewdly thought out, making Agent 47's world one which you will want to go back to again and again. Despite the linear narrative in the game and the ineviable ending, how you get there is what makes this game unique. You notice new things as you go back and play again, noticing different geographical approaches or the fact you completely missed a secure room which takes you on a different route to achieve your assassination(s).

The AI need a mention in my review for the vast improvement the developers have made, contrasting previous titles. They are much more intelligent in every sense you can think of when approaching a conventional stealth assassin game. They no longer blow your brains out for wanting to go through a door that is restricted, they just become aware and suspicious of you for wanting to do so. They will ask you to leave, if you do not comply, that's when they logically gun you down. Also, you can no longer hide in the most ridiculous place as the AI will look if they're suspicious of you being in there... for instance, if you shoot from a building and your notoriety shoots up, if you're in a building with a closet and you get in, they will get you out of there... the game prepares you to be more of a stealth killer, or just more prepared for the mini army about to come and get you.  A final mention on the AI is the fact they can see right through your disguise if you do not use them wisely. If you put on a disguise, but have irregular patterns or do suspicious things, their awareness will raise and they'll eventually warn all other staff and before you know it everybody is coming after you. This again engages you to be much more shrewd about your assassination if you take the stealth approach to the game.

All in all a beautiful looking and atmospheric game which captivates throughout. The rebuild of the engine has made for great animation with amazing lighting effects and shadows and immaculate detail for a 2006 title. The only negative I can possibly fathom is that the camera can sometimes be a little awkward in tight spaces, such as an elevator, however this takes nothing from the overall playability of the game. It's definitely worth picking up at normal price, but at it's current discounted rate it would be crazy not to!

Pros:

- Enthralling and story-line that gives many hours to feast upon.
- Beautiful scenery in each level and a great atmosphere.
- Extremely easy to pick up and play due to it's incredible playability.

Cons:

- Camera can be awkward at times.

Rating: A stolid 9.8 out of 10.

reviewText:
IO Interactive did a lot of things right in this installment of the Hitman series. Each level was well crafted, provided a reasonable challenge, and offered a multitude of ways to beat the level. This is a stealth action game with emphasis on non combat and discovering a sequence of events that will lead to the completion of each level.

Pros: The overall presentation of the game was much better than the previous two games with cut scenes between each level and a good story arc. The biggest improvement has to be the multiple ways of approaching each level.  You could beat the level one way then talk to a buddy who did the same level a completely different way. The music was used well to heighten the mood when need be. As expected the graphics and game mechanics have been improved.

Cons: Although many paths exist for completing a level, Blood Money still suffers from the fact that once a sequence has been found for beating the level it is pretty easy.  However, this is still way better than the previous two games.  The game is only just good.  There are not many epic memorable moments and you never feel that involved with the level.

If you like the stealth action genre then this is a must play.
Score: 8.5/10

reviewText:
One of the very best games of the past generation. Hitman: Blood Money again has you perform several assassinations as the 'bald killer clone' Agent 47. You are dropped in about a dozen large maps, and have to figure out how to accomplish a set of tasks, which of course always include assassinations, as silently as possible. As a result, the game is essentially a puzzle game, and a very good one at that. No level has just one solution for attaining the optimal 'silent assassin' rating, which makes replaying levels worthwhile, as should be obvious from my time spent on the game.

Perhaps one of the game's strongest qualities is the variety in level themes, it takes you to snowy mountain villas, quiet suburbs, underground nightclubs, redneck weddings and many other locales. All this is scored by one of the generation's finest soundtracks by composer Jesper Kyd.

Blood Money is significantly more refined than its predecessors, which while good, are a bit too rough around the edges for the average gamer. This is also essentially Hitman's last hurrah. While Hitman: Absolution is not an irredeemably terrible game, it does move away from what is the core of the franchise. Where in Blood Money, the focus is clearly on planning and figuring out the solution, Absolution switches it more towards execution. I think the appeal of the two games as a result is rather different, this aside from several design issues Absolution has with one of its core mechanics.

reviewText:
Pros
+Huge amount of freedom in how you take on your assignments. Do you swap a fake gun for a real one, and watch as your target gets killed onstage, or do you snipe him unseen from a balcony? Or do you just rush in with a shotgun and eliminate everybody and anybody? It's your choice!

Cons
-In game, resolution options are limited, and you may need to edit the .ini files to get one that matches your monitor.
-Limited amount of weapons to customize, and all upgrades can be bought fairly quickly.
-Not a whole lot of missions (13 total, and 1 is a linear tutorial, and the last one isn't really an assassination, so it's more like 11), but the replay value makes up for it.

reviewText:
Although I did not expect much of this Hitman iteration, it turned out to be more than just decent. Hitman: Blood Money is by some considered to be 'the better' Hitman game. Although it obviously has an edge over its predecessors as far as graphics and sound effects are concerned, it did a lot of things right.

The graphics are decent for its time. While there are definitely some graphics glitches (most ragdoll related), it does not fail to immerse the player. The effects of lighting has been taken advantage of and at this point in the game development industry there's a healthy emphasis on textures except for skyboxes.

The gameplay is solid and has only minor glitches that you will likely not even trigger unless you start experimenting. Regardless, none of the glitches you will run into should break the game or your perception of the atmosphere and storyline. And don't get me wrong, it had the potential to go terribly wrong here: the gameplay hooks in on the story and immersion, it could not exist without the storyline, and the storyline would not be convincing without the mechanics this game has to offer. Luckily there's nothing to be afraid of in this regard.

The music is fitting and blends the environment and story together. A proper use of sounds and quality voice acting make it the story much more enjoyable.

Buy it if you haven't played it yet! Hitman: Blood Money is one of those classics that you should try at least once. It is a good quality game that today's videogame industry should consider looking into as reference material.

reviewText:
Pros
+Huge amount of freedom in how you take on your assignments. Do you swap a fake gun for a real one, and watch as your target gets killed onstage, or do you snipe him unseen from a balcony? Or do you just rush in with a shotgun and eliminate everybody and anybody? It's your choice!
+Graphics are fairly decent for an early 7th gen game, and most systems should run it easily.
+Great soundtrack by the legendary Jesper Kyd.
+Good voice acting.
+Solid game mechanics. Everything, from the disguise system to weapon customizing adds to the game, and doesn't feel like shallow filler.
Cons
-In game, resolution options are limited, and you may need to edit the .ini files to get one that matches your monitor.
-Limited amount of weapons to customize, and all upgrades can be bought fairly quickly.
-Not a whole lot of missions (13 total, and 1 is a linear tutorial, and the last one isn't really an assassination, so it's more like 11), but the replay value makes up for it.
-Story isn't that interesting, but you can skip the cutscenes at any time, and I don't think people play these games for the story anyway.

Overall
Being my first Hitman game, I really enjoyed it. The numerous ways to eliminate your targets and open ended levels add lots of replay value, the game looks nice, and although the story is lacking, it's not awful. Buy it when you have the chance.

Although I did not expect much of this Hitman iteration, it turned out to be more than just decent. Hitman: Blood Money is by some considered to be 'the better' Hitman game. Although it obviously has an edge over its predecessors as far as graphics and sound effects are concerned, it did a lot of things right.

The graphics are decent for its time. While there are definitely some graphics glitches (most ragdoll related), it does not fail to immerse the player. The effects of lighting has been taken advantage of and at this point in the game development industry there's a healthy emphasis on textures except for skyboxes.

The gameplay is solid and has only minor glitches that you will likely not even trigger unless you start experimenting. Regardless, none of the glitches you will run into should break the game or your perception of the atmosphere and storyline. And don't get me wrong, it had the potential to go terribly wrong here: the gameplay hooks in on the story and immersion, it could not exist without the storyline, and the storyline would not be convincing without the mechanics this game has to offer. Luckily there's nothing to be afraid of in this regard.

The music is fitting and blends the environment and story together. A proper use of sounds and quality voice acting make it the story much more enjoyable.

Buy it if you haven't played it yet! Hitman: Blood Money is one of those classics that you should try at least once. It is a good quality game that today's videogame industry should consider looking into as reference material.

The Hitman series has always been known for its mix of stealth and action gameplay, and this entry of the series is no different.

The game plot is revealed by a series of interview pieces with a retired police officer, in which he usually tells something about the death of a certain person that most people thought something (a different story to the public) and turns out it was something entirely different involving 47.
At first these don't make much sense, but as you play the game, you start to see where the plot is going, there aren't many remarkable points on it with the exception of the ending (which is amazingly delivered), so no spoilers.

The gameplay of this game follows the tradition of the old entries of the series, which is a good thing since it is what makes this series unique: you receive a briefing showing the place, who you have to eliminate, the background story of said person/people, then you choose your starting equipment and you are ready to go. What makes the game unique is that you can play in a stealth approach: observing enemy patrols, finding out how to infiltrate certain places, and planning a way to get close enough to take out your target or even how to take them down from afar.

One of the main features of the game that is still intact is that 47 is still a master of disguises and has the ability to change his clothing in seconds (it may sound a little weird, but it explains how someone can do the stuff he pulls off), which in most cases is the only way to access certain locations in the game. For instance, only workers can enter a part of the opera house that is still being build, I mean, you can enter without disguise, but that will attract attention AND the guards of the place.

An addition made in this game, is that now 47 can move faster while sneaking, in previous games, it was hard and painful to sneak around because it was too slow. He can now throw coins around to lure people to someplace where them and 47 can have a more personal conversation" or simply use them to lure guards out of posts and such.

reviewText:
I first played this game on the PS2, and still love it for the PC. While graphics aren't top-knotch, and it doesn't have an incredibly long list of missions to play through, Blood Money can offers hours of entertainment. Either go the route of the silent assassin and stealthily take out targets or go a more...dynamic route and just put holes in everything and everyone. No people, no witnesses, right?

Anyway, this game is loads of fun, and is by far the best in the Hitman series in my opinion. It takes multiple play-throughs to truly experience all that the developers have put into the game.

I would highly recommend this game!

reviewText: It's almost like a puzzle action game, with the player trying to figure out how to assassinate the targets with (ideally) not getting caught. The stealth is different from other stealth games, since it's all about hiding in plain sight. The player must acquire and use disguises to avoid suspicion. While you can go through the game guns blazing, it's more more fun and rewarding going through the game stealthily.\n\nI highly recommend this for stealth action fans.
